utterance: Whoa, hush! Whoa haw, there! What are you afeard of now? That's nothin' but a jay squallin'.
speaker: driver of the oxen

utterance: I didn't go to skeer your oxen, stranger, and was standin' still to let 'em pass, but thet jay squalled at me, an', lookin' this way, I s'pose they ketched a glimpse of my fur cap an' took it for some varmint. Cattle is always lookin' for some sech, in the woods. Your load's all right, I hope,
speaker: hunter

utterance: Why, you've got women an' childern,
speaker: hunter

utterance: You're comin' in to make a pitch. How far might you be goin', stranger?
speaker: hunter

utterance: A little beyond Fort Ti, on this side,
speaker: Seth Beeman

utterance: I made a pitch there last year. My name's Seth Beeman, and I come from Salisbury, Connecticut, and them on the sled are my wife and children.
speaker: Seth Beeman

utterance: I want to know! A Beeman from ol' Salisbury, An' now I wonder if you be akin to my ol' comrade in the Rangers, 'Zekiel Beeman?
speaker: hunter

utterance: My father's name was Ezekiel, and he served in Roger's Rangers.
speaker: Seth Beeman

utterance: Give me your hand, friend,
speaker: Job Carpenter

utterance: Well, I never thought to meet an friend here in these lonesome woods, to-day. Yes, an ol' friend, for that's what a son of 'Zekiel Beeman's is to me, though I never sot eyes on him afore. You've maybe hearn him speak of Job Carpenter? That's my name.
speaker: Job Carpenter

utterance: Carpenter? Yes, the name sounds familiar, but you know father wa'n't a man of many words and never told us much of his sojerin' days.
speaker: Seth Beeman

utterance: You're right, he wa'n't. We all larnt to keep our heads shut when we was a-scoutin' an' a loud word might cost a man his'n an' many another life.
speaker: Job Carpenter

utterance: An' so these is your wife an' childern, be they?
speaker: Job Carpenter

utterance: How dedo, marm. How dedo, little uns. Tol'able comf'table, I hope?
speaker: Job Carpenter

utterance: Wal, I'm glad you're goin' to be nigh the Fort. There's always a doctor there, an' it's sort o' protection, if the garrison be reg'lars. Now, Seth, start up your team, an' I'll boost on the sled till it's square on the road again.
speaker: Job Carpenter

utterance: How far be we from the Fort?
speaker: Seth Beeman

utterance: Nigh onto five mile,
speaker: Job Carpenter

utterance: After a spell you'll come to a better road on the ice of the crik, if you take the first blazed path beyend here, to your left. It'll fetch you to my cabin, where you'd better stop till morning, for you can't no ways git to your pitch till long arter nightfall. I know where it is, for I come across it, last fall, when I was trappin' mushrat up the crik. My shanty's the first thing in the shape of a dwelling that you'll come to, an' can't miss it if you foller the back track of my snowshoes. It hain't no great, but it's better'n no shelter, an' you're more'n welcome to it. Rake open the fire an' build you a rouster, an' make yourselves to home. I've got some traps to tend to, but I'll be back afore dark,
speaker: Job Carpenter

utterance: What on airth is it?
speaker: Seth Beeman

utterance: 'Tain't of the airth, but of the water,
speaker: Job Carpenter

utterance: I killed it on the ice of the lake airly in the winter. One of the sojers at the Fort see it, an' he says it's a seal fish belongin' to the sea, where he's seen no end on 'em. But them sojers to the Fort is an ign'ant set like all the reg'lars, that we rangers always despised as bad as they did us, an' it don't look no ways reasonable that sech a creatur' could come all the way up the St. Lawrence, an' the Iriquois River, an' most the len'th o' this lake. My idee is, it's a fresh-water mare-maid, an' natʼral to this lake.
speaker: Job Carpenter

utterance: An ol' Injin told me that there's always ben one o' these cretur's seen in this lake a spell afore every war that's ever ben. But I hope the sign 'Il fail this time. I've seen enough o' war an' I don't see no chance of another, all Canady bein' took an' the Injins in these parts bein' quilled.
speaker: Job Carpenter

utterance: The sunrise gun to Fort Ti,
speaker: Job Carpenter

utterance: They hain't no other use for their powder now.
speaker: Job Carpenter

utterance: An' that's Crown P'int Fort, ten- mile furder down the lake. They help to keep us from getting lonesome up here in the woods.
speaker: Job Carpenter

utterance: I don't sca'cely ever go nigh the forts,
speaker: Job Carpenter

utterance: I don't like them reg'lars an' their toppin' ways.
speaker: Job Carpenter

utterance: Why,
speaker: Seth Beeman

utterance: it's a bear, an' if he's been to the camp, I'm afraid he's done mischief, for they're meddlesome creatur's. But there wa'n't much left there for him to hurt,
speaker: Seth Beeman

utterance: I can't think of nothing but the hunk of pork we had to keep the big kittle from b'ilin' over,
speaker: Nathan

utterance: and a little mite of syrup that we left in the little kittle 'cause there was more'n we could carry home in the pails.
speaker: Nathan

utterance: He's welcome to that if he's left the pork; we hain't no pork to feed bears.
speaker: Seth Beeman

utterance: Oh, father,
speaker: Nathan

utterance: to think we've got a bear. Won't mother and Marthy be proud? and won't Job think we're real hunters?
speaker: Nathan

utterance: Never shoot at 'em,
speaker: Job Carpenter

utterance: if you do, you won't hit 'em. Always shoot under, a mite or more, accordin' to the depth o' water.'
speaker: Job Carpenter

utterance: It's the sloop from St. Johns,'
speaker: Job Carpenter

utterance: She comes two or three times, whilst the lake's open, with stores for the garrison to the Fort. It's an easier trail than the road from Al
speaker: Job Carpenter

utterance: They hain't nothin' to do with their powder nowadays, but to fool it away in sech nonsense. Arter all it's better use for it than killin' folks, erless it might be Injins.
speaker: the Ranger

utterance: Oh, mother, when do you s'pose the folks to the Fair will get the gris' mill done?
speaker: Nathan

utterance: Afore long, I hope, for your sake, my boy. Let me spell you awhile and you take a good rest.
speaker: mother

utterance: Oh, mother, they're carryin' the stones and fixin's for the new mill, and the man says they'll be ready for grindin' before winter sets in. Then it'll be good-by to you, old' Up-an'-down,' and good riddance to bad rubbage.
speaker: Nathan

utterance: Don' revile the plumpin' mill, Nathan. It's been a good friend in time o' need. Mebby you'll miss the trips to Skeenesborough with your father. You've always lotted on them.
speaker: mother

utterance: Yes, but I'd rather go to the Fort and play with the boys, any day, and I'll have more time when samp pound-in' is done and ended.
speaker: Nathan

utterance: Really, William, if this be a specimen of your terrible Yankees, they be very like our own people, in speech and actions, only sharper witted, and they surely show close kinship with us in spite of such long separation.
speaker: the commandant's lady

utterance: You little know them. They are a turbulent, upstart breed. I fear only a sound drubbing, and, perhaps, the hanging of a score of their leaders, will teach them obedience to His Majesty.
speaker: Captain Delaplace

utterance: I would be sorry to have this little man drubbed or hanged. surely he is not of the stuff rebels are made of.
speaker: the commandant's lady

utterance: The very stuff, my dear. Bold and self-reliant, and impatient of control, as you may see. If ever there comes an outbreak of these discontented people, I warrant you'll find this boy deserving the drubbing and getting it, too, for His Majesty's troops would make short work of such rabble.
speaker: Captain Delaplace

utterance: Hello, here's a clearin'. Jenkins, tell Mr. Felton there's a fenced clearin' here, -and boy.
speaker: unspecified

utterance: Stake.
speaker: Jenkins

utterance: Hold on, boy. You stay here till Mr. Felton comes up.
speaker: unspecified

utterance: I'm going home. if Mr. Felton wants me he can come there.
speaker: Nathan

utterance: You sassy young rascal. you stand where you be or I'll-
speaker: unspecified

utterance: You wouldn't dast to.
speaker: Nathan

utterance: A fine clearing, indeed. I wonder what Yankee scoundrel has dared to so seize, hold and occupy the lands of the Royal Colony of New York.
speaker: Mr. Felton

utterance: Mayhap this younker can tell you, sir.
speaker: unspecified

utterance: Boy, what scoundrel has dared to steal this land and establish himself upon it without leave or license of His Excellency, the Governor of New York? Yes, and cut down the pine trees, especially reserved for the mast-ing of His Majesty's navy.
speaker: Mr. Felton

utterance: It's holler, Mr. Felton.
speaker: Jenkins

utterance: Who stole this land? Where's your tongue, boy?
speaker: Mr. Felton

utterance: Oh, father, there's a whole lot of Yorkers come and they're runnin' a line right through our clearin'.
speaker: Nathan

utterance: Take this to Newton's and show it to the men folks, and say 'There's trouble to Beeman's,' and then go on and do the same at every house, 'round to Job's, and show it to him. and tell him the same, and do whatever he tells you. Be spry, my boy; I must stay here and ta' care of mother and Sis. Keep in the woods till you get clear of the Yorkers, then take the road and clipper.
speaker: Seth Beeman

utterance: Hello, where are you bound in such a hurry, and who might you be?
speaker: a stranger

utterance: I'm Seth Beeman's boy, and I'm goin' to neighbor Newton's of an arrant.
speaker: Nathan

utterance: Ah,-Beeman,-a good man, I'm told. And what might take you to neighbor Newton's in such a hurry? Has that hemlock twig in your hand anything to do with your errand? Speak up. You need not be afraid of me.
speaker: a stranger

utterance: Did you ever hear of Ethan Allen?
speaker: a stranger

utterance: Oh, yes; only yesterday father told about Ethan Allen's throwing the Yorker's millstones over the Great Falls at New Haven.
speaker: Nathan

utterance: Right and true! Well, I am Ethan Allen. Your father sent you with that twig to say there's trouble at Beeman's, didn't he?
speaker: Ethan Allen

utterance: My horse's feet will help you make your rounds quicker than yours, my man. We've no time to lose, for there's no telling what those scoundrels may be at. Eight Yorkers! Well, we'll soon raise good men enough to make short work of them.
speaker: Ethan Allen

utterance: Why, colonel, we wa'n't expectin' on you so soon, but we hain't no less glad to see you. 'Light and come in. Mother'll hev potluck ready to rights. Why, is that the Beeman boy stickin' on behind you? Anything the matter over to Beeman's?
speaker: Newton

utterance: No, we can't 'light. Do your errand, my boy, and we'll push on.
speaker: Ethan Allen

utterance: Trouble to Beeman's, now.
speaker: Nathan

utterance: Yea, verily, Rise up and gird on your swords, you and your sons. The Philistines are upon you even as it has been prophesied. Felton and his gang of land thieves. The son of Belial was warned to depart from the land of the elect, but he heeds not those who cry in the wilderness. Confound the rascal! He must be 'viewed'! You and your two boys take your guns and jog down that way, and as you go cut a goodly scourge of blue beech, for verily there shall be weeping and wailing and gnashing of teeth. We'll rally the Callenders, and Jones, and Harrington, and North, and my friend Beeman here will tell Job. We'll gather a good dozen. Enough to mete out the vengeance of the Lord to eight Yorkers, I'll warrant!
speaker: Ethan Allen

utterance: You go straight to Job and do as he tells you;everybody lay low and keep dark till you hear the owl hoot.
speaker: Ethan Allen

utterance: Plague on 'em all with their pitches and surveyin' and squabblin'. Why can't folks let the woods alone? There's room enough in the settlements for sech quarrels without comin' here to disturb God's peace with bickerin's over these acres o' desart. I thought I'd got done wi' wars and fightin's, exceptin' with varmints, when the Frenchers and Injins was whipped. But I guess there won't never be no peace on airth and good will to men for all it's ben preached nigh onto eighteen hundred years. Plague on your Hampshire Grants and your York Grants, the hul bilin'! Wal, if it must come it must, and I'll be skelped if I'll see Yorkers a runnin' over my own Yankee kin. Yorkers is next to Reg'lars for toppin' ways. I never could abear 'em.
speaker: Job Carpenter

utterance: And Ethan Allen's in these betterments? Well, them Yorkers 'll wish they'd stayed to home. He's hard-handed, is Ethan.
speaker: Job Carpenter

utterance: 'Tain't your mother's cookin', but it's better'n nothin'.
speaker: Job Carpenter

utterance: It's quicker goin' by water 'n by land.
speaker: Job Carpenter

utterance: What is it, Seth?
speaker: Ruth Beeman

utterance: The Yorkers have come.
speaker: Seth Beeman

utterance: Our folks 'll come to help as soon as they can, but the Yorkers 'll get here first. Look a there.
speaker: Seth Beeman

utterance: It won't come to that, will it?
speaker: Ruth Beeman

utterance: I hope not, but I want the gun out of their reach and where I can get it handy. There ain't a bullet or buckshot in the house. Give me some beans. They're good enough for Yorkers.
speaker: Seth Beeman

utterance: Well, Mr. Beeman, I sent your son to bring you to me, but it seems you did not please to come.
speaker: Mr. Felton

utterance: No, it does not please me to leave my affairs at the beck and call of every stranger that comes this way.
speaker: Seth Beeman

utterance: Well, sir, I'd have you understand that I am Marmaduke Felton, duly appointed and licensed as a surveyor of His Majesty's lands within his province of New York. Furthermore, be it known, I have come here in the regular discharge of the duties of my office, to fix the bounds of land purchased by my client, Mr. Erastus Graves, of the original grantees, with patent from His Excellency the Governor, who alone has authority to grant these lands. I find you, sir, established on these same lands be- longing to my client. What have you to say for yourself? By what pre- tended right have you made occupa- tion of lands belonging to my client?
speaker: Mr. Felton

utterance: I have to say for myself that I bought this pitch of the original pro- prietors, and I have their deed, duly signed and sealed. They got their charter of His Excellency Benning Wentworth, His Majesty's Governor of the Province of New Hampshire.
speaker: Seth Beeman

utterance: Your title is not worth the paper it's written on. Governor Wentworth has no more authority to grant lands than I have. Not a whit. The east bounds of New York are fixed by royal decree at the west bank of Connecticut River, as everybody knows, and Wentworth's grants this side that limit are null and void. No doubt you have acted in good faith, but now there's nothing for you but to vacate these better- ments forthwith; yes, forthwith, if you will take the advice of a friend.
speaker: Mr. Felton

utterance: I shall not go till I am forced to. When it comes to force both parties may take a hand in the game.
speaker: Seth Beeman

utterance: Very well, very well! I have given you friendly advice; if you do not choose to take it the consequences be on your own head. Come, Graves; come, men, let us go about our pres- ent affairs;We shall be back to spend the night with you, Mr. Bee- man. You cannot refuse Mr. Graves the shelter of his own house.
speaker: Mr. Felton

utterance: I can't help it, but you will not be welcome.
speaker: Seth Beeman

utterance: I wish you a pleasant night on't.
speaker: Seth Beeman

utterance: Don't be fright- ened, my girl. They won't get us out of here. Keep a stout heart and wait.
speaker: Seth Beeman

utterance: Do hear the owls hootin', and it's clear as a bell. It can't be it's a-going to storm.
speaker: Ruth Beeman

utterance: I shouldn't wonder if it did. Where was that nighest hoot?
speaker: Seth Beeman

utterance: Why don't Nathan come home? I hain't seen him all day. I wish he'd come. He'll get ketched in the storm.
speaker: Martha

utterance: Oh, don't worry, deary.
speaker: unspecified

utterance: We might as well eat, for there's no telling when father 'll be back.
speaker: mother

utterance: I'm afeard our York friends won't enjoy their lodgin's overmuch. The owls are round pretty thick to-night.
speaker: father

utterance: Well, I guess they've ben talking to you.
speaker: Ruth Beeman

utterance: Can owls talk?
speaker: Martha

utterance: Well, the old knowing ones. Owls are turrible knowing creatur's.
speaker: father

utterance: Here's to your speedy installment in your rightful possessions. Now, help yourself, and give the men their tot.
speaker: Mr. Felton

utterance: Good evening, gentlemen. Good evening, Mr. Felton and Graves.
speaker: Ethan Allen

utterance: Colonel Ethan Allen. Most happy to receive a call from so distinguished a person. A very fortunate meeting.
speaker: Mr. Felton

utterance: You are my prisoner. Men, lay hold of him! A hundred pounds are offered for his head! It is Ethan Allen! Lay hold of him, I tell you!
speaker: Mr. Felton

utterance: The first man that draws a pistol or raises a gun gets a bullet through his carcass.
speaker: Ethan Allen

utterance: Down with your gun over there! Oh, it is our friend Beeman! All right!
speaker: Ethan Allen

utterance: Come in, men!
speaker: Ethan Allen

utterance: Keep every one of these men under close guard, my boys, especially these two chief offenders. Now, Mr. Felton, perhaps it is made plain to you that I am not your prisoner, and that the gods of the valleys are not the gods of the hills. Behold how riches take to themselves wings and fly away, even before they are possessed. In witness whereof, consider the hundred pounds offered by your Governor for an honest man. No wonder he longs for the sight of one, with such a pack of thieves and land jobbers as he has about him.
speaker: Ethan Allen

utterance: An honest man? A ruffian! A rioter! A defier of law!
speaker: Mr. Felton

utterance: Go on, Master Felton, go on. Ease yourself. Unless it be prayer, which you rarely employ, I doubt, there is nothing like good round cursing to relieve an overburdened heart. Upon occasion I avail myself of the remedy. Pray go on, or give your friend a chance. Mr. Graves, you have the floor.
speaker: Ethan Allen

utterance: Well, if you have offered all your burnt offerings of brimstone, let the men have their supper and make themselves strong for their journey. Dish up the pork, cook, that you have been bumping my legs to get at, and bring out your bread bag. Stir yourselves. We have weighty business pending.
speaker: Ethan Allen

utterance: Friends of the Grants, you all know we have come here to erect the 'Judgment seat' this night, and mete out such punishment as doth unto justice appertain. Yea, verily, for wrongs done or sought to be done upon the people of these New Hampshire Grants. We will at once elect a judge. To save time, I will nominate Ethan Allen as a proper person for that office. You that would elect him say 'Aye.'
speaker: Ethan Allen

utterance: Contrary minded, make the usual sign.
speaker: Ethan Allen

utterance: No
speaker: Mr. Felton

utterance: You are not entitled to vote in this meeting, sir. I have a clear majority and will take my seat.
speaker: Ethan Allen

utterance: Now, friend Beeman, tell us your story.
speaker: Ethan Allen

utterance: Now, you have it all. Felton and Graves are here, as you see, in prosecution of their unlawful business, as the testimony of this boy and his father shows. In further proof whereof, see the surveyor's instruments here in view. What say you, men of the Grants, are they guilty or not guilty?
speaker: Ethan Allen

utterance: Guilty
speaker: various voices

utterance: What shall be their punishment? That they be chastised with the twigs of the wilderness?
speaker: Ethan Allen

utterance: I don't go agin these men a gittin' what they desarve, but I don't want to have them skinned. Their skins hain't worth a-hevin' only for their selves, and I hate to see white men whipped like dogs. If they was Injins I wouldn't say agin it. But, bein' they hain't, I move they hev jest nine cuts o' the Blue Beech apiece.
speaker: Job Carpenter

utterance: This is to Certify that the Bearer has this day rec'd his Just Dues and is permitted to pass beyond the New Hampshire Grants. He Behaving as Becometh. In witness whereof, see the Beech Seal upon his back and our Hands set Hereunto. Signed, Ethan Allen and others.
speaker: Ethan Allen

utterance: Now, depart, and woe be unto you, Marmaduke Felton and Erastus Graves, if you ever set foot in the land of the Green Mountain Boys. You other men, if you come in peace and on honest business, you shall not have a hair of your heads hurt. But if you ever venture to come on such an iniquitous errand as now brought you, by the Great Jehovah, you shall repent in sackcloth and ashes! Forward, march!
speaker: Ethan Allen

utterance: You don't know of anybody hereabouts that wants to hire a good hand, I s'pose?
speaker: a stranger

utterance: Nathan, Nathan, come here quick!
speaker: Martha

utterance: Who be them?
speaker: Martha

utterance: I guess they're Injins, and I guess they're a-trappin' mushrat. Let's run over to the bank and see.
speaker: Nathan

utterance: Yes, they be Injins, and I wish they'd let my mushrat alone. But I s'pose there's enough for them and me.
speaker: Nathan

utterance: How do? You Beenum boy?
speaker: Indians

utterance: Yes.
speaker: Nathan

utterance: Be you gettin' many mushrat?
speaker: Nathan

utterance: No ketch um plenty. Ol' Capenteese ketch um mos' all moosquas.
speaker: Indians

utterance: Me come back pooty soon. Den go house, see um Beenum. Buy um some pig eese. S'pose he sell um lee'l bit?
speaker: Indians

utterance: What in tunket, has that old sow got outen the pen?
speaker: Nathan

utterance: It's a bear, and he's down cellar.
speaker: Nathan

utterance: He dead. You boy do dat?
speaker: Indians

utterance: You big Nad-yal-we-no. Too much good for be Pastoniac. You come 'long me to Yam-as-ka, I make you Waubanakee. Den be good for sometings. Nawaa.
speaker: Indians

utterance: We've killed him. We've killed a bear.
speaker: Nathan

utterance: I can't get down cellar, for I dasn't open that door. What be we goin' to do?
speaker: Nathan

utterance: What does keep father so?
speaker: Ruth Beeman

utterance: I guess you'd better go and see what henders father so. I can't think what it is. I hope it hain't anything.
speaker: Ruth Beeman

utterance: Perhaps he's gone over to Callendars or some o' the neighbors. I hain't heard a tree fall for ever so long nor his axe a goin' for a long time.
speaker: Nathan

utterance: Mebby he's cut his foot or something.
speaker: Martha

utterance: I can't hear nothin' of him for all the air's so holler and everything sounds so plain. You'd better go and see what henders him. Mebby he can't git home.
speaker: Ruth Beeman

utterance: Father! father!
speaker: Nathan

utterance: I hate him. He's sassed me every day since I come here, and I've got a bigger job 'an that to settle, one that I'd ha' settled with his father, if he hadn't cheated me by gettin' killed.
speaker: Silas Toombs

utterance: Oh, what do you mean? I thought you and Seth was always good friends.
speaker: Ruth Beeman

utterance: Friends! I hated the ground he walked on. Look here.
speaker: Silas Toombs

utterance: Yes, Ethan Allen and Seth Beeman and his neighbors whipped a man for claimin' his own, and your boy went and gethered 'em in. Mebby you re'collect it.
speaker: Silas Toombs

utterance: I couldn't help it. I didn't see it. I run and hid and stopped my ears.
speaker: Ruth Beeman

utterance: Well, 'Rastus Graves 'ould ha' settled his debts if he'd ha' lived. But he died afore his back got healed over, and afore he died he turned the job over to his brother, that's me, Silas Tombs, or Graves-they're the same in the end.
speaker: Silas Toombs

utterance: Well, I've got Seth Beeman's wife, and, what's wuth more, his farm, an' his childern right 'nunder my thumb. I hope he knows on't. And now, ma'am, you don't want to breathe a word o' this to your nice neighbors or to your young 'uns. It wouldn't do no good and it might be unpleasant all round. You don't want folks to know what a fool you be.
speaker: Silas Toombs

utterance: You lazy whelp, what you putterin' 'bout? You spend half your time a gawpin. You git them ashes housed afore noon or I'll give ye a skinnin', and I'll settle an old score at the same time.
speaker: Silas Toombs

utterance: "You know what I told you, and Silas Toombs doesn't go back on his words; no, sir."
speaker: Silas Toombs

utterance: "I couldn't do it. I tried, but I couldn't get 'em all done!"
speaker: Nathan

utterance: "Come down, you little devil, or I'll shoot you."
speaker: Silas Toombs

utterance: "I won't," you can't shoot with an axe."
speaker: Nathan

utterance: "I'm glad you made me think on't. Then come down or I'll chop you down!"
speaker: Silas Toombs

utterance: "Hello! Come down! Don't be a fool! An' I won't lick you. The tree's comin' an' it'll ki. you."
speaker: Silas Toombs

utterance: "Nathan, Nathan,"
speaker: Silas Toombs

utterance: "Your boy has run off, Mis' Toombs. You needn't worry. He'll git starved out 'fore long and sneak back. And he'll work all the better when he does come. Boys has got to have their tantrums an' git over 'em."
speaker: Silas Toombs

utterance: "Like's not he's over to the Fort. They'll make him stan' round, I tell ye."
speaker: Silas Toombs

utterance: "Be quiet, Gabriel; what is't troubles you."
speaker: Job Carpenter

utterance: "Why, Nathan, come in my boy, come in, the hound won't hurt you. Ain't he a pictur'? Did you ever see such ears? Did you ever see such a chest and such legs? And he's as good as he is harnsome. I went clean to Manchester arter him and gin three prime beaver skins for him. He's one o' Peleg Sunderland's breed and 'll foller anything that walks, if you tell him to, from a mushrat to a man. And as for his voice, good land! You hain't never heard no music till you hear it. That's what give him his name, Gabriel. But what's the matter with you, Nathan?"
speaker: Job Carpenter

utterance: "You look clean beat out. There hain't nothin' the matter with your folks?"
speaker: Job Carpenter

utterance: "I'd ha' gin a dozen mushrat skins to seen him when he got the tree down and didn't find you, and him like a fool dog a barkin' up a tree an hour arter the coon 'd left it. You done right to come to me, for he won't come here to look for ye right off. And then when he's had time to cool off and git ashamed of himself, you can go home."
speaker: Job Carpenter

utterance: "No," I'll never go back till I'm old enough to lick him and make him sorry I come."
speaker: Nathan

utterance: "Oh, well, you think you will. But you won't never. The rough edge 'll be wore off afore you git round to it. Once I swore I'd thrash a schoolmarster I hed, and when I went to do it we jes' sot down and talked over old times, like ol' friends. But what 'll your mother and sis do without you?"
speaker: Job Carpenter

utterance: "They'll be better off without me. I can't help mother any, nor she me, yet awhile. Can't you let her know I'm safe some way?"
speaker: Nathan

utterance: "Oh, yes, I'll happen round there some day to rights. How in tunket did she ever come to mate wi' that surly red-haired dog? You know I hain't seen her since they was married. Women is onaccountable critters, anyhow, an' I've been marcifully presarved from ever bein' tackled to one on 'em;"
speaker: Job Carpenter

utterance: "Well, what news?"
speaker: Nathan

utterance: "Well, I happened in just arter noon. Your nice stepfather sot by the fireplace a smokin'. 'Where's Nate,' says I, an' he up an' answered mighty quick, 'Run away, but he'll be back quick enough.' Your mother was lookin' turrible worrited, an' it was quite a spell afore I could git a chance to do my arrant with Toombs right in the room. Bimeby I made out to have a turrible pesterin' sliver in my right hand an' got your mother to pick it out wi' a needle. I'd ruther have a leg took off 'an to have a woman jabbin' at a sliver. Whilst she was at it, me wi' my back towards Toombs, I whispered you was at my house and all right, an' you'd ortu seen her face light up. Then we played the sliver was out, an' arter I'd wished you was to home to go fishin' with me an' wondered what on airth you'd run away f'm such a good home for, I come off. An' I tell you, boy, that ere ol' scoundrel thinks he's killed you. When I come off towards where he chopped that tree, he follered along to see if I went nigh it, an' all the time I could see he was scairter 'n he was mad."
speaker: Job Carpenter

utterance: "I don't care, I can't go back if you'll let me stay with you."
speaker: Nathan

utterance: "Sartainly, an' glad to have you."
speaker: Job Carpenter

utterance: "Your mother stuck this out of the loft winder as I come away,"
speaker: Job Carpenter

utterance: "Oh, I am glad to get this, and see, it is longer 'n I be yet. But I'm growing, for I measured when Toombs put this up loft so't he could hang his gun on the hooks over the fireplace. See, I can hold it at arm's length long enough to see to shoot,"
speaker: Nathan

utterance: "Toombs was out a burnin' log heaps," She says he's dretful narvous an' jumps at every sound. I ruther guess he's gittin' his pay as he goes along, my boy."
speaker: Job Carpenter

utterance: "Whativer has coom o' your red-headed stepfather? He didn't coom here sin he coom marryin' your mother,"
speaker: an English boy

utterance: "I've somehow missed my way on the lake," I'm bound for Bennington. Can you give me and my poor beast shelter till morning and then set me on the right road ?"
speaker: a traveller

utterance: "Sartainly, come in, come in," You're welcome to such as I've got of bed an' board, an' your hoss 'll be better off in the shed wi' corn fodder 'n he'd be a browsin' in the woods."
speaker: Job Carpenter

utterance: "I like to remember such things about a place that has been so famous," I would like to visit the fort sometime? How many men did you count the last time you saw them parade, did you say?'
speaker: a traveller

utterance: "It's about time to quit trappin' for this year," They're gettin' a leetle off prime, though better'n they be in the fall an' no kits as there is then," Good land! What's Gabe hullabalooin' at now, I wonder?"
speaker: Job Carpenter

utterance: "It's neighbor Newton. I'll go up loft."
speaker: Nathan

utterance: "Job, have you heard the news?'
speaker: Newton

utterance: "News ? What news?"
speaker: Job Carpenter

utterance: "There's ben a fight down in the Bay Colony 'twixt our folks and the king's troops and our folks whipped 'em.'"
speaker: Newton

utterance: "Our folks a fightin' the king's troops?"
speaker: Job Carpenter

utterance: "I al'ys said them reg'lars, shootin' breast high at nothin', couldn't stan' agin our bushfighters, aimin' to kill," but what next, Dan'l ?"
speaker: Job Carpenter

utterance: "War-it means war. The country's all a-risin'. Every man's got to choose the side he'll take. Which side is yourn, Job?"
speaker: Newton

utterance: "I've hoped to end my days in peace. I've had enough o' fightin', the Lord knows. When I've fit it was for the land I was born in-if it was under the British flag-an' I shan't never fight for no other."
speaker: Job Carpenter

utterance: "Every man in these clearin's is all right, so far as we know, exceptin' that aire sour-faced Toombs. He hain't no good will towards our side. A Tory in Seth's shoes, and him red-hot for liberty. He's got a Canuck a-workin' for him, and I'd livser trust a wolf 'n one o' them pea-soupers. I hain't no patience wi' Ruth for marryin' that critter. Where do you s'pose her boy is?"
speaker: Newton

utterance: "Well, what do you think o' the news, my boy?"
speaker: Job Carpenter

utterance: "Oh, is it true about the fight? How I wish I could go and help our folks. Father 'd go quick."
speaker: Nathan

utterance: "Well, well, stay where ye be. If it goes on, it's sure to strike the ol' war-path,"
speaker: Job Carpenter

utterance: "Well, here you be," I s'pected as much t' other day when I see the extry knife an' pile o' mushrats. Say, Job, how is't? Can I speak out afore him consarnin' the business we was talkin' on ?"
speaker: Newton

utterance: "To be sure. He's close-mouthed an' he's achin' to go an' jine our folks down in the ol' Bay Colony."
speaker: Job Carpenter

utterance: "Good; he's the same stuff as his father." There's a plan all fixed to take Ti and Crown P'int. It seems a Connecticut feller named Brown started the thing a-goin' some weeks ago. There's nigh ontu two hunderd and fifty men in the Grants engaged to do the job. Ethan Allen commands. We muster at Beeman's Crik, day after to-morrow night. You'll be there?"
speaker: Newton

utterance: "Me, too; let me go, too."
speaker: Nathan

utterance: "He's a stout lad an' he handles a gun like a man. Let him come,"
speaker: Job Carpenter

utterance: "But how be we goin' to git across the lake ? There hain't boats enough hereabouts to take more'n thirty men to oncet.'"
speaker: Newton

utterance: "Colonel Skeene's is goin' to be borrowed, an' there's a plan to git some more without askin' at Crown P'int; with them an' what we can pick up we'll make enough. How many'll your birch carry?"
speaker: Newton

utterance: "Six men that's used to such craft, but not one lummax.'"
speaker: Job Carpenter

utterance: "Well, bring it along. Everything of the boat kind'll be needed. Toombs troubles me most. He's on the fence, which means he ain't to be trusted. He'll see our men a musterin' an' s'pect what's up, an' let the garrison know some way. He and his Canuck has got to be watched."
speaker: Newton

utterance: "Easy done! We can tie 'em, neck an' heels, an' leave 'em to take keer o' theirselves."
speaker: Job Carpenter

utterance: "You don't want to aim that way," Lord, how I've heard Major Rogers swear to see the reg'lars wastin' lead, shootin' int' the tree tops wi' the enemy fair afore 'em! Fightin' hain't no foolin'. Aim to kill, jes' as ye would at a pa'tridge. There-that's the talk,"
speaker: Job Carpenter

utterance: "Where on airth is that dog? He mistrusted somethin' was up and run off. He'd ortu be tied up, but we can't wait any longer, an' he'll hafter run loose. Wal, le's be off."
speaker: Job Carpenter

utterance: "I've follered it for many a day,' an' I never thought to go agin it. But I b'lieve I'm right,"
speaker: Job Carpenter

utterance: "'Down, Gabe,'"
speaker: Nathan

utterance: Friends of the Grants, we are already enough for this business in hand, but there are more to come. There will be boats enough to cross us all in good time. Keep quiet Cook your rations and eat your supper. To-morrow we'll eat our breakfast in Ticonderoga, or know the reason why.
speaker: Ethan Allen

utterance: I thought Newton was goin' to tend to them critters. Newton, didn't you put a guard over Toombs and his man ?
speaker: Nathan

utterance: Toombs is safe in care of a good man, but his Canuck couldn't be found. I guess he's too stupid to do any mischief, anyway.'
speaker: Newton

utterance: Well, he's ben a sneakin' round here an' now he's gone, an' there's no tellin' where. Where's Toombs's boat?
speaker: Nathan

utterance: Here,
speaker: Newton

utterance: Gabe's round here somewheres,
speaker: Nathan

utterance: Jest the one I was a wishin' for,'
speaker: Job Carpenter

utterance: Good fellow, good fellow. Now, Newton, we'll ketch that skunk. Here, here, old boy,
speaker: Job Carpenter

utterance: The fox has slipped,
speaker: Job Carpenter

utterance: but never mind. If he can fool Gabe he's a smart 'un. Ruth, where's somethin' that 'ere Canuck has wore ?
speaker: Job Carpenter

utterance: Hisn? There couldn't be nothin' better. See here, Gabe.
speaker: Job Carpenter

utterance: Sarch him out, boy. Sarch him out,
speaker: Job Carpenter

utterance: I knowed it, and I'll bet ye there'll be a Canuck treed afore sundown.
speaker: Job Carpenter

utterance: Hello de Forrt, Hey! Hello de Forrt! Sacre chien! Go home, Ah tol' you! Hello, Carillon. Tac-con-derrrque! All de Bastonais was comin' for took you, Ah tol' you! Sacre chien! Stop off you nowse so Ah can heard me spik.
speaker: his Canuck

utterance: Shut yer head an' come down out o' that mighty quick,
speaker: Job Carpenter

utterance: Me no onstan' Angleesh,
speaker: his Canuck

utterance: Hello de Forrt!
speaker: his Canuck

utterance: Looka here, I don't want tu be obleeged tu hurt you, but stop yer hollerin' an' come right down.
speaker: Job Carpenter

utterance: Me no onstan', Ah tol' you! Hello-.
speaker: his Canuck

utterance: Ah comin'! Ah comin'! Don't shot some more!
speaker: his Canuck

utterance: Well, boys, whathiver it was, Hi don't hear nothink more of it. But Hi'll 'ail the shore. 'Ello there, whathiver is the row?
speaker: the sergeant

utterance: 'Ah't was some o' thim Yankee divils huntin' just, and that's all about it. Divil a word could I make out but the dog yowlin' an' a man phillalooin', an' thin the shot. They kilt whathiver they was at an' thin wint away.'
speaker: Murphy

utterance: Hi believe you're right, Murphy, an' we'll no bother to go ashore, but just pull back and report to the captain,
speaker: the sergeant

utterance: I don't claim no credit for't. It was all Gabe's doin's, an' if I'd left him tied up to hum as I laid out to, our cake would all 'a' ben dough.'
speaker: Job Carpenter

utterance: Here, Newton, here's your man. Put him under guard with that Tory, Toombs,
speaker: Ethan Allen

utterance: Why, it's one of Sunderland's dogs, that haven't their equal in New England.
speaker: a tall man of noble, commanding presence

utterance: You've got an eye for houn' dogs, Capt'n Warner. He sartain is one o' them dogs an'll foller anything he's told to, though 't ain't no gre't trick to track a Canuck more'n an Injin. They're both strong-scented critters.
speaker: Job Carpenter

utterance: Men, fall in for a moment. Here, is Mr. Benedict Arnold. He bears a colonel's commission from the Connecticut Committee of Safety, and claims the right to command you to-night. Men of the Green Mountains, whom do you follow-Arnold or Allen ?
speaker: Ethan Allen

utterance: Allen, Allen,
speaker: unspecified

utterance: Sir, I submit to the will of these men, but let me be a volunteer in this glorious enterprise. The Green Mountain Boys and their famous leader are too generous to refuse this.
speaker: Mr. Benedict Arnold

utterance: Indeed, so brave a man as I well know you to be, is most welcome, and, by the Great Jehovah, if the men don't object, you shall be second in command.
speaker: Ethan Allen

utterance: Here, this is the youngster, Colonel Arnold, that Mr. John Brown tells of in this paper, whom he saw and conversed with last winter about Ticonderoga.
speaker: Ethan Allen

utterance: You have such a chance to serve your country as don't often fall to a boy. Will you lead us into the Fort to-night? Will you do it faithfully?
speaker: Ethan Allen

utterance: Speak,
speaker: Ethan Allen

utterance: If the commandant's lady won't be hurt, I will,
speaker: Nathan

utterance: So the lady is a friend of yours. Well, never fear. We may disturb her morning nap, but she shall not be harmed. We are not waging war in the wilderness against women and children. Here, my boy, stick this twig of hemlock in your hat. Don't you see we've all mounted it? There, now, you wear the Green Mountain Boy's cockade. See that you never disgrace it.
speaker: Ethan Allen

utterance: The lazy-bones, What has gone wrong? Daylight will betray us if we wait much longer. What do you say, my men-shall we wait, and maybe lose our best chance of success, or go on with what strength we have?
speaker: Ethan Allen

utterance: Fall in, in three ranks!
speaker: Ethan Allen

utterance: I want no man to go against his will. You that wish to go with me, poise arms.
speaker: Ethan Allen

utterance: Shoulder arms! Right face! Forward, march!
speaker: Ethan Allen

utterance: I swear, I will not yield my right. I planned this enterprise. My money set it on foot. I swear I will command, and not yield my right to Ethan Allen or the devil.
speaker: Mr. Benedict Arnold

utterance: What shall I do with this fellow? Put him under guard ?
speaker: Ethan Allen

utterance: Gentlemen, for the sake of the good cause, don't quarrel. Yield a little, both of you. Share the command equally, and enter the Fort side by side.
speaker: Captain Callender
addressee: Ethan Allen and Mr. Benedict Arnold

utterance: For the sake of the cause I agree to this.
speaker: Ethan Allen

utterance: Quick, my boy, show me the commandant's quarters,
speaker: Ethan Allen

utterance: Come forth, commandant, come forth.
speaker: Ethan Allen

utterance: Come out of your hole, you damned old skunk,
speaker: Ethan Allen

utterance: Who are you and what do you want ?
speaker: Captain Delaplace

utterance: I want the Fort and all it contains. Surrender, instantly.
speaker: Ethan Allen

utterance: Surrender? Is this a mad joke or treason ?
speaker: Captain Delaplace

utterance: Neither; but honest men claiming their own. Surrender.
speaker: Ethan Allen

utterance: In whose name? By whose authority?
speaker: Captain Delaplace

utterance: In the name of the Great Jehovah and the Continental Congress.
speaker: Ethan Allen

utterance: I know no such authority.
speaker: Captain Delaplace

utterance: Sir, do you deny the authority of the King of Kings? And Congress seemeth to have some power here this morning. Waste no more time. We are four to your one. Do you surrender ?
speaker: Ethan Allen

utterance: I see no choice. But it consoles me that you rebels will hang for this.'
speaker: Captain Delaplace

utterance: You are welcome to the consolation of the hope, but it gives me no uneasiness and I run no new risks. I am Ethan Allen. You may have heard of me and have lusted for the shekels the sons of Belial offer for my head. But get on your clothes and parade your men without arms. Madam, pardon the intrusion, but my business is urgent. Permit me to close the door.
speaker: Ethan Allen
addressee: Captain Delaplace and the commandant's lady

utterance: This is a pretty kettle of fish,'
speaker: Captain Delaplace

utterance: Courage, my dear; this handsome giant has something of the manners of a gentleman, and will not let a lady be maltreated by his rebel band.
speaker: Captain Delaplace

utterance: Oh, William, the Fort surprised, and we prisoners, and not a blow struck for defense.'
speaker: the commandant's lady

utterance: There could be no defense with such numbers. Well, there's no use crying over spilt milk. Did you see that pet cub of yours with the big rebel? What did I tell you?
speaker: Captain Delaplace

utterance: Hurrah, boys, it's our friends with the British sloop. Give her three cheers.
speaker: Ethan Allen

utterance: Give 'em powder for powder, boys. Fire,
speaker: Ethan Allen

utterance: We're getting towards home.
speaker: Job Carpenter

utterance: Yes, I've been thinking of home and mother and sis. Guess I needn't be afraid of ol' Toombs any longer, but I don't know as I could keep my hands offi'n him. I always meant to give him a thrashing when I could.
speaker: Nathan

utterance: Mebby you could, now, but he's a cordy critter and a soople one; but mind what I tell you, you never will.
speaker: Job Carpenter

utterance: Look a-here, Nate, there's some trouble to your mother's. She's sent word for you to come right home. Old Toombs is dead or run off to Canerdy, or something. I don't know the rights on't. But, anyhow, she wants you bad.
speaker: one of the young Newtons

utterance: It's come out about as I told you, but I wan't expectin' nothin' like this, poor critter. He thinks you're a spirit come to haunt him. Then he called loudly to the figure, It's the boy. It's Nathan, alive and well. Don't be afeared, he won't hurt ye.
speaker: Job Carpenter

utterance: He sort o' broke down after the guard went away, an' t'other day we found him all of a heap down by a big hemlock log that he never got round to cut up. He hain't seemed to sense much since. He's been dreadful worried about you, Nathan, all along, ever since you went away.
speaker: Ruth Beeman

utterance: I wouldn't tell her, She'd feel bad, an' that wouldn't pay any more'n it does to nurse a grudge. Vengeance don't belong to us, poor critters.
speaker: Job Carpenter
